Description: Mechanics is the study of the motion of objects, divided into kinematics and dynamics. Kinematics deals with describing motion, while dynamics relates motion to forces.

An idealized object treated as a point without rotational or vibrational considerations. Often used to approximate real objects in motion.", Earth and Sun can be considered particles with respect to the distance between them.
The rate at which a particle's position changes over time. It involves both direction and magnitude.
Example: If a person travels 100m north in 20 seconds, the average velocity is 5 m/s north.

Description: The velocity at any given instant, derived as the limit of average velocity as the time interval approaches zero.
Example: If a car speeds up from rest, its velocity at a specific second can be calculated using the equation for instantaneous velocity.

Description: The rate of change of velocity with respect to time. It can change in magnitude or direction, or both.
Example: When a car accelerates from 0 to 60 km/h in 5 seconds, the acceleration is 12 km/h/s.

Description: Motion where acceleration is constant, occurring along one axis. The equations describe velocity and position over time.
formula: v = vd + at; x = xd + vdt + (1/2)at²
Example: If a ball is dropped from a height, its velocity and position at any moment can be determined by these equations.
